overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a practical approach to time-series forecasting with limited data and anomalies. It focuses on identifying daily seasonality, handling a suspicious constant-value day as an anomaly, and using simple averaging heuristics due to insufficient data for complex modeling. The method prioritizes data availability and pattern consistency over sophisticated algorithms.
common_data_patterns: Anomaly detection (constant values interpreted as data errors)
Handling of limited historical data (96 points)
key_insights: Exclusion of anomalous days (constant values) from modeling
Averaging same-hour values across valid days to capture daily patterns
Repetition of averaged daily patterns for multi-day forecasts
Rounding outputs to match input data precision (3 decimals)
Prioritization of recent data when historical patterns are limited
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Combines data validation, anomaly handling, and heuristic modeling while acknowledging limitations like insufficient data for weekly seasonality analysis or advanced algorithms.
